content:
ASIA-PAC

White House said the date for US President Trump and Chinese President Xi meeting has not been set and that negotiations continue with all options available. (Newswires) 

US told Germany to stop allowing Huawei to operate or face intelligence sharing being pared back. (WSJ) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM May went to Strasbourg for talks with European Commission President Juncker in which there are hopes the sides will work on a legally binding commitment that neither the UK nor EU would seek to indefinitely keep the backstop, although sources stated this does not mean there will definitely be a deal and an EU source also commented that they remain firm in rejecting UK Attorney General Cox's idea whereby the UK would in effect have a unilateral right of exit from the backstop. Furthermore, ITV's Peston had earlier suggested that UK PM May’s visit to Strasbourg was contingent on whether the EU improved its offer. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK Cabinet Ministers are reportedly being briefed by PM May's Deputy on what is in the process of being agreed in Strasbourg, according to BBC’s political editor. Separately, there were also reports that the ERG believes UK Attorney General and Number 10 have some kind of deal to put to Parliament tomorrow, although ERG's Baker was doubtful UK PM May has achieved aim of replacing backstop with alternative arrangements. (Newswires/BBC)

UK PM May spokesman said the Cabinet will meet on Wednesday morning before the spring fiscal statement, while the spokesman added that talks are ongoing at a technical level and Brexit deal documents will be voted upon on Tuesday which have to be submitted tonight. In related news, UK PM May spokesman confirmed PM May is committed to hold the three votes this week (Meaningful vote Tuesday, no-deal Brexit Wednesday and extending A50 Thursday). (Newswires)

Tory Brexiteer source said there is a large whipping operation for Conservative lawmakers to back UK PM May's deal tomorrow and that they are being promised billions of additional pounds for schools and the police if the deal goes through. (ITV)

There were earlier reports that EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier and Commissioner Secretary General Selmayr told EU27 ambassadors’ mood with UK was 'confrontational' and Commons vote was destined to fail, while the EU is ramping up no-deal preparations and are eyeing May 24 as Brexit extension date. (FT)

BoE's Haskel (Neutral) said it is conceivable that, like Article 50, the UK will require more time than the 21 months, while he added it is possible there might be another round of negotiating and attendant uncertainty. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC will meet with shale drillers tonight. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Special Representative for North Korea Biegun said they are taking the reports regarding North Korean missile site seriously and doesn't know what message they are trying to send. (Newswires) 

US

US Retail Sales (Jan) M/M 0.2% (Prev. -1.2%, Rev. -1.6%). (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Nvidia (NVDA) and Mellanox (MLNX) both surged after the former agreed to acquire the latter for USD 6.9bln in cash, outbidding Intel’s (INTC) previous USD 6bln offer. Apple (AAPL) outperformed after BAML turned bullish on the iPhone maker. Boeing (BA) traded with large losses in the wake of the 157-casualty Ethiopian Airlines flight crash of a Boeing 737 Max 8; Southwest Airlines (LUV), whose fleet consists of mainly 737 Max 8s, also sold off. Newmont (NEM) drifted lower on the announcement of its Nevada JV with Barrick Gold (GOLD), with Barrick removing its previous full acquisition offer. Baker Hughes (BHGE), Halliburton (HAL), Schlumberger (SLB) and National Oilwell (NOV) were all outperformers following Goldman Sachs initiating the oilfield services sector with Buy ratings, in particular Baker Hughes, which it gave a Conviction Buy rating. Eli Lilly (LLY) sold off, whilst Elanco (ELAN) made gains following Eli Lilly’s completion of its share exchange offer for Elanco. Weyerhaeuser (WY) and Facebook (FB) benefitted from upgrades at BMO Capital and Nomura Instinet respectively. SPX +1.47% at 2783, NDX +2.11% at 7164, DJI +0.79% at 25651.

The relatively upbeat risk sentiment has seen the Treasury curve steepen slightly (though 2s5s and 2s10s were a touch narrower). Analysts cited Powell’s positive comments on Friday (economy healthy), which contributed to some of the downside, though the main catalyst was likely equities bouncing back despite heavyweight Boeing trading red (see stock specifics). The Treasury sold new 3-year notes today at the lowest yield in a year; but although cover was in line with recent averages, the auction tailed by 0.4bps (average over the last six was 0.2bps tail). There wasn’t too much to take from the internals; indirect takedown rebounded on the month to the highest since December. US T-note futures (M9) settled 4 ticks lower at 122-20+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 11 March 2019: Hopes of Brexit progress as May to meet Juncker/Barnier on eve of Meaningful Vote
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 11 March 2019: Hopes of Brexit progress as May to meet Juncker/Barnier on eve of Meaningful Vote

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Brexit optimism ahead of Tuesday’s Meaningful Votes; headline US retail sales beats, although priors revised further downward; Saudis to extend cuts into April; Boeing’s 737 Max 8 jet crashes again.

* AHEAD: Australian NAB Conditions & Confidence, UK GDP (Estimates) & Industrial Production, US CPI, Japanese Corporate Goods & Machinery Orders, UK HoC Vote on PM May’s Brexit Deal, Fed’s Powell & Brainard Speaking, RBA’s Debelle Speaking, US 10yr Note Auction.

 

* US RETAIL SALES: The headline 0.2% MM was a touch better than the consensus view looking for 0.0%; ex-autos was also above consensus, as was the control group. However, there was some chunky downward revisions to the December data, which was already disappointing. Pantheon say the revisions imply a 0.2ppt downward revision to Q4 GDP growth, but say that is not the end of the story: "The official data are subject to endless further revisions, and we remain of the view that eventually they will be revised higher, in keeping with past experience when the numbers undershoot the Redbook," Pantheon said. "To be clear, we are not arguing here that the true rate of growth of retail sales remains at last year's peak; that can’t happen, given the fading boost from the tax cuts and the drop in gas prices in Q4. But the December plunge probably overstates the downshift substantially." Pantheon also says the details of the January report suggest the rebound was uneven, but overall "these data signal a clear increase in total consumers' spending in January, but the adverse base effect from December's drop - which will be revised down - means that Q1 real consumption will struggle mightily to reach 2% growth, and a mere 1% is entirely possible," Pantheon notes.

* TRUMP 2020 BUDGET: As expected, the Trump budget proposed spending cuts for Federal Agencies (ex defence, which got a boost). Growth was projected at 3.0% or above over the horizon. Crucially, analysts note that the Budget aims to achieve balanced accounts by 2034 – GOP budgets usually aim to achieve this within a decade, highlighting the deficit-friendly nature of Trump policies. A Bloomberg reporter tweeted that Trump's first budget projected a USD 488bln deficit for fiscal 2020, two years later, his latest budget projects a USD 1.101trln deficit; revenue is USD 337bln less than he had projected (on tax cuts), though spending is USD 276bln higher.

* BREXIT: Ahead of this week's series of votes on Brexit, UK PM May is in Strasbourg this evening for last-minute negotiations with EU President Juncker and EU Brexit negotiator Barnier. There is optimism that she will be able to secure concessions that will allow UK AG Cox to change his legal opinion of May's deal, which would make it more palatable to Brexiteers and the DUP (who essentially do not want a permanent backstop arrangement on the Irish border). In terms of the mechanics, there are hopes that the Tusk/Juncker's January letter can be turned into a protocol—which would be legally binding, and would then give Cox ammunition to change his legal advice. The Spectator explained that "the theory goes that if the backstop were to become permanent, it would contradict the Good Friday Agreement as it would replace North/South cooperation with a UK/EU construct; so, the UK could use this protocol to the withdrawal agreement to justify quitting the backstop if it was clearly becoming permanent." May will arrive in Strasbourg at 9pm local time (8pm London time), and a statement is expected. There were some concerns in the day that, if May's deal fails as expected on Tuesday, she could scrap the vote on the Wednesday on a no-deal Brexit, and the vote on Thursday to extend the Article 50 process, though these concerns were dismissed by UK government officials. Back to this week’s votes, as it stands, assuming no additional concessions are secured, the assumption is that May would lose the vote, which would lead to a vote on a no-deal Brexit on Wednesday, and then a vote to extend Article 50 on Thursday. For this evenings events, tonight’s focus is on a unilateral UK statement interpreting temporary nature of backstop to allow Cox to alter his legal advice. Idea is EU will give tacit approval by not objecting, a Sun reporter said. Other reporters have tempered enthusiasm; BBC’s Watt said a Cabinet minister told him that the negotiations in Strasbourg were “not looking good.”

* WTI (J9) SETTLES $0.72 HIGHER AT $56.79; BRENT (K9) SETTLES $0.84 HIGHER AT $66.58. Brent bounced back on Monday after news that Saudi Arabia will extend the production cuts it has already announced for March into April. "Saudi has been producing below the 10.3mln BPD quota agreed as part of the OPEC+ production cut plan since early this year, and had guided to a production level of 9.8mln BPD in March," UBS O&G desk said, "the latest comment that April production will also be 'well below' 10mln BPD is a positive for oil, but should not come as a surprise." The bank explains that the Saudis have consistently shown signs that it intends to tighten the market, and UBS says it will likely continue to do so while concerns about global economic growth, and US/China trade talks weigh on sentiment. "The 4Q18 oil price collapse likely left Saudi and its OPEC+ allies concerned about how easily the group can lose its grip on oil prices, with the result that there seems now to be widespread acceptance of the idea that ceding market share to defend a higher price is the economically optimal choice," UBS added. Ahead of this week’s energy inventories, Genscape reportedly forecasts a draw of 671k barrels at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub.

* SPX +1.47% at 2783, NDX +2.11% at 7164, DJI +0.79% at 25651. SECTORS: Energy +1.54%, Materials +1.41%, Industrials +0.89%, Cons Discretionary +1.53%, Cons Staples +1.33%, Healthcare +1.17%, Financials +0.99%, Tech +2.17%, Telecoms -1.86%, Utilities +0.73%.

* US EQUITIES: BAML active managers' holdings update reports active managers' rotation into defensives is picking up again. Morgan Stanley says evidence is building for further slowing, says the stock correction likely not over. Nomura quants say systematic stock selling pressure caused by the liquidation of long positions will likely calm down after the middle of next week.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Nvidia (NVDA) and Mellanox (MLNX) both surged after the former agreed to acquire the latter for USD 6.9bln in cash, outbidding Intel’s (INTC) previous USD 6bln offer. Apple (AAPL) outperformed after BAML turned bullish on the iPhone maker. Boeing (BA) traded with large losses in the wake of the 157-casualty Ethiopian Airlines flight crash of a Boeing 737 Max 8; Southwest Airlines (LUV), whose fleet consists of mainly 737 Max 8s, also sold off. Newmont (NEM) drifted lower on the announcement of its Nevada JV with Barrick Gold (GOLD), with Barrick removing its previous full acquisition offer. Baker Hughes (BHGE), Halliburton (HAL), Schlumberger (SLB) and National Oilwell (NOV) were all outperformers following Goldman Sachs initiating the oilfield services sector with Buy ratings, in particular Baker Hughes, which it gave a Conviction Buy rating. Eli Lilly (LLY) sold off, whilst Elanco (ELAN) made gains following Eli Lilly’s completion of its share exchange offer for Elanco. Weyerhaeuser (WY) and Facebook (FB) benefitted from upgrades at BMO Capital and Nomura Instinet respectively.   

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 4 TICKS LOWER AT 122-20+. The relatively upbeat risk sentiment has seen the Treasury curve steepen slightly (though 2s5s and 2s10s were a touch narrower). Analysts cited Powell’s positive comments on Friday (economy healthy), which contributed to some of the downside, though the main catalyst was likely equities bouncing back despite heavyweight Boeing trading red (see stock specifics). The Treasury sold new 3-year notes today at the lowest yield in a year; but although cover was in line with recent averages, the auction tailed by 0.4bps (average over the last six was 0.2bps tail). There wasn’t too much to take from the internals; indirect takedown rebounded on the month to the highest since December.

* PREVIEW: 10-YEAR AUCTION (USD 24bln, Tuesday 1300 EDT/1700 GMT): The previous 10-year auction was weak, with cover matching a 12-month low, combined with a tail size at a 12-month high, with the latter largely a result of investment fund participation slipping. And the recent richening of the 10-year may keep investors side-lined; Barclays notes that on-the-runs are trading more special than older 10s when compared with previous auction cycles, and the bank argues that that suggests a build-up of a short base as the auction sets up. Barclays says it continues to maintain its recommendation to fade the liquidity premium in on-the-runs (the Feb 2029) vs. older 10s (the Aug 2028); “OnTR10s have cheapened 0.5bp in forward space. However, they still appear somewhat rich on the curve, especially if they do not end up trading as special as priced in the repo market.” Six auction averages: High-yield 2.954%, tail -0.2bps, cover 2.45x, dealers 25.8%, directs 10.6%, indirects 63.6%.

* GBP: Brexit was the top performer in G10 FX with hopes rising that the UK and EU are on the cusp of a breakthrough that would allow UK Attorney General Cox to change his legal pinion of the irish backstop, and win support of Brexiteers and the DUP to support May’s deal on Tuesday. GBP has found its way to the 1.3150 ahead of comments from May/Juncker later tonight. Assuming that nothing changes (and May does not secure further concessions), there are four scenarios for GBP and tomorrow’s vote, Barclays bank says. SCENARIO 1: Meaningful Vote fails (Tue)/no-deal blocked (Wed)/vote to extend A50 passes (Thu) (scenario is mostly likely, as things stand, without further concessions); Barclays says initial GBP reaction would be negative. Focus will then shift to 21 March summit, where any signs of a longer extension could lead to a rally. SCENARIO 2: Meaningful Vote passes (somewhat likely); Barclays says it could open the door for new post-referendum highs. SCENARIO 3: All votes fail (unlikely); Barclays sees GBP real effective exchange rate -2.5% as markets price higher probability of no-deal Brexit. Focus then shifts to 21 March summit where GBP will be almost entirely sensitive to Brexit newsflow. GBP SCENARIO 4: meaningful vote fails/MPs vote for no-deal (highly unlikely); Barclays says GBP REER -5%.

* USD: The DXY is slightly negative, while the EUR and JPY are more or less flat; the DXY was a function of data; the Jan data surprised to the upside, but December’s grim print was revised down further, seeing the USD sell-off, before stabilising around the cash open. US CPI is on the slate for Tuesday, though it is likely that both today’s data does little to change Fed pricing, and ahead of the inflation data tomorrow, it would likely take more than one decent print to put the Fed back onto its hiking trajectory.

* EUR: For the EUR, analysts note that the narrowing of the Bund/BTP spread and Bund/Treasury spread should be supportive of the EUR, though that is not being seen, likely due to the fact that the currency is pro-cyclical, and concerns about global growth (and specifically, Eurozone growth, as evidenced by the ECB last week) is keeping a lid on action. Additionally, SocGen believes that despite the narrowing in rate differentials, we’d still need to see Bund yields tick up for the EUR to catch any meaningful lift.

* JPY: Dollar-yen was heading south after the European session got underway, though as US equities opened firmer, the haven was sold after finding a floor around 111.00, rising to highs around 111.30. Analysts said the it was typical BTD activity, though the 100- and 200-dma (at 111.34 and 111.41 respectively) seem to be capping upside.

subject: Tory Brexiteer source says there is a large whipping operation for Conservative lawmakers to back UK PM May's deal tomorrow, ITV reports
content:
• "Tory Brexiter source: "there is a massive whipping operation to press us into voting for PM's deal tomorrow. We are being promised billions of additional pounds for schools and the police if deal goes through. Some will buckle. But enough of us are focused on the more important question of whether we'll still be in the backstop in five years". What also matters is that the Brexiters of the ERG are committed to vote with Northern Ireland's DUP if they continue to believe the union is threatened by the backstop. But if DUP decides in the end to vote with the PM - which, truthfully, looks unlikely - that does not mean the Tory ERG Brexiters will do the same. The relationship between ERG and DUP is asymmetrical in that sense." 
  • Via ITV's Peston

BREXIT - Situation report ahead of May's trip to Strasbourg
content:
• Ahead of this week's series of votes on Brexit, UK PM May is in Strasbourg this evening for last-minute negotiations with EU President Juncker and EU Brexit negotiator Barnier. There is optimism that she will be able to secure concessions that will allow UK AG Cox to change his legal opinion of May's deal, which would make it more palatable to Brexiteers and the DUP (who essentially want to see that the UK is not locked-in to the Irish backstop for a long, undetermined amount of time). In terms of the mechanics, there are hopes that the Tusk/Juncker's January letter can be turned into a protocol—which would be legally binding, which would then give Cox to change his legal advice. The Spectator explained that "the theory goes that if the backstop were to become permanent, it would contradict the Good Friday Agreement as it would replace North/South cooperation with a UK/EU construct; so, the UK could use this protocol to the withdrawal agreement to justify quitting the backstop if it was clearly becoming permanent." May will arrive in Strasbourg at 9pm local time (8pm London time), and a statement is expected. There were some concerns in the day that, if May's deal fails as expected on Tuesday, she could scrap the vote on teh Wednesday on a no-deal Brexit, and the vote on Thursday to extend the Article 50 process, though these concerns were dismissed by UK government officials. 
  • Note: we published this situation report yesterday highlighting the key themes ahead of Tuesday's Brexit vote.

subject: US to auction USD 38bln 3-year notes at 1300 EDT/1700 GMT
content:
THIS WEEK'S NET TREAUSRY SUPPLY USD 54BLN: The US Treasury will auction USD 78bln of new 3s, 10s re- opening, 30s re-opening; with USD 24bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, net supply is implied at USD 54bln. No Fed add-ons. 

RECENT PERFORMANCE: The uncertain outlook, risk asset jitters, and the prospect of no Fed hikes on the horizon has supported front-end of the Treasury curve recently; the market prices no hikes this year, with pricing tilting towards cuts in 2020. TD Securities expects this week's auctions to go well given their expectation for no further coupon auction size increases ahead, and the fact that rates have remained relatively stable. 

3-YEAR AUCTION (USD 38bln, Monday 1300 EDT/1700 GMT): The previous 3-year auction was solid, extending the run of lower stop-out rates at 3s auctions to four at 2.502%, stopping-through for the first time in 11-months. Dealer participation was the lowest since early 2018, offset by firm domestic investor demand. Barclays notes: “The new 3y note will be eligible for inclusion in the TUM0 deliverable basket and is a potential CTD candidate. The security will be the shortest maturity alongside the current seasoned 5y note (1.875s of Mar22s) and a future 2y Mar22 note. We believe the 3y WI is appropriately rich relative to current 3s.” Six auction averages: High-yield 2.767%, tail 0.2bps, cover 2.56x, dealers 41%, directs 12%, indirects 47%.

Daily FX Wrap: Sterling storms back amidst speculation about Brexit soiree in Strasbourg
content:
GBP/NOK

Still the G10 outliers, but now both in the ascendency and outperforming as the Pound rebounds sharply and impressively on renewed hopes that UK PM May can salvage a deal with the EU that might sway Tuesday’s meaningful vote in her favour. After the latest rounds of talks and negotiations, the EU offered a compromise on the backstop that is said by Brussels to have been close to bridging the gap between the 2 sides, but then rejected by UK Government. However, May and Juncker have spoken again by phone since and rumours are circulating, although not confirmed that the former could be heading to Strasbourg to receive another alternative offer which could break the deadlock. Some are also suggesting that Barnier will be in attendance, adding more momentum to the 11th hour Brexit deal bandwagon, with Cable building on recovery gains above 1.3000 and only stalling a few pips from 1.3100 vs a low of around 1.2950 at one stage, and Eur/Gbp extending its retreat from 0.8675 highs to sub-0.8600. Note, this puts a big bank trade recommendation back in the money as it shorted the cross at 0.8630, looking for 0.8400 and with a stop at 0.8730. All eyes/ears now turning to Brexit Minister Barclay standing in for PM May. Elsewhere, the Norwegian Krona held the bulk of its inflation data gains on the 9.7600 handle vs just over 9.8260 before the much firmer than expected headline and core CPI prints that underscored Norges Bank rate hike expectations for next Thursday.

NZD/AUD 

The next best majors and both clawing back a bit more lost ground vs their US rival after eagerly awaited US retail sales data for January flattered to deceive with better than anticipated headline prints somewhat sullied by downward revisions to the previous month that was already grim. The Kiwi maintained its dominance down under and hit 0.6835 at best, while the Aussie managed to climb above 0.7050 to reach 0.7065, but could not cross 1.0350 vs the Nzd.

EUR/CAD

Both ending pretty muted Monday EU sessions just a shade firmer vs the Greenback, with the single currency still anchored around 1.1250 and flanked by tech levels and options either side within a broader 1.1200-1.1300 range (like a 1.1270 Fib, 1.1200 and 1.1300-20 expiries in 1.7 bn and 2.7 bn respectively). Meanwhile, aside from the aforementioned post-data Usd dip, which saw the DXY slip just below 97.200 at worst, the Loonie derived some momentum from an upturn in oil prices after a Saudi Arabian official indicated sub-7 mn bpd exports in April. Note, Usd/Cad recoiled a bit further from last week’s peak to probe under 1.3400 before consolidating just above the big figure again.

JPY/CHF 

The major laggards as broad risk sentiment stabilised and the Jpy retreated towards 111.30 lows vs around 110.90 at the other end of the spectrum, while the Franc touched 1.0100 again from 1.0070 as Eur/Chf held between 1.1315 and 1.1355 approximately.

subject: Morgan Stanley says evidence is building for further slowing, says the stock correction likely not over
content:
• The bank notes S&P 500 is -7% from highs, around the same as CY19 EPS forecasts. Says evidence grows that these forecasts have more downside risk. Says not to trust the strong rally on bad 4Q results, adds that the correction is not over until margin pressures stabilize, which means defensives are likely to resume leadership.
  • Consensus CY19 EPS forecasts for the S&P 500 are down -6% from their September peak, on par with the 6.5% decline in the S&P 500
  • In the past week we have received further confirmation that our primary thesis is playing out. "The tax cuts enacted in late 2017 likely caused the Fed to tighten more quickly than they would have otherwise and also caused the US economy to overheat," MS writes, "this overheating created excesses in both the labor market and supply chains that now need to be wrung out of corporate costs."
  • MS says evidence of this cost rationalization is starting to show up in the data. "Last week's jobs report was disappointing with one of the weakest payrolls numbers and the highest wage cost reading since the economic recovery began in 2009," and adds that "job cut announcements also spiked last week to the highest reading since July 2015, and finally, Amazon reportedly stopped ordering product from many of its wholesale vendors, perhaps as a sign they are trying to reduce inventory costs."
  • MS believes that our call for a boom/bust (made almost three years ago is well advanced): "many investors under-appreciated how markets in 2017 were discounting 2018's coming boom and failed to see how markets in 2018 would discount the oncoming bust of 2019. It makes sense that they are now underestimating the negative impact that will have on behavior like capital spending, which we think is the next major area of disappointment."
  • MS says the most recent earnings season was unusual in that, on average, companies lowering guidance tended to move higher both immediately following the guidance revisions and over the next few days. "We think this kind of 'dip buying' on guidance signals confidence in a trough, but wearen't as sure," and notes that "the last time the market saw guidance dips being bought in this way was around guides for 1Q15, a period which ultimately did not reflect the trough for earnings revisions.

subject: BAML active managers' holdings update reports active managers' rotation into defensives is picking up again
content:
• BAML says managers' exposure to cyclical sectors relative to defensive sectors fell for two straight months, reflecting concerns around slowing global growth, rising volatility and geopolitical uncertainties.
  • Funds' underweight in Staples may also be starting to bottom out, BAML says — after managers reduced their exposure for nearly five straight years — as the relative weight in the sector rebounded slightly from last month’s record low level.
  • Tech loses its charm among fund managers, BALM says; less than a year ago, Tech was the most crowded sector among large cap active managers, now ranks fourth among managers' overweights, and its relative weight today is at a three-year low. A big driver of this decline has been the Software industry; Communications Equipment reached its record low level of positioning in BALM's data history going back to 2008.
  • Consumer Discretionary relative weight rose to a four-month high, grew more overweight by fund managers, while active managers' relative exposure to Automobiles also jumped to its highest level since June 2016.
  • Active crowding risk continues to play out, BAML says, noting that the 10 most overweighted stocks by long-only managers continued to underperform the 10 most underweighted stocks year-to-date. And passive continues to take share from active, where 15% of the total S&P 500 float is now owned by passive US equity mutual funds and ETFs
  • BAML says their client flows also suggest the rotation out of single stocks into ETFs may be back for now, in a reversal from trends in Jan and early February.

subject: ANALYSIS: US Retail sales show January rebound, Pantheon Macroeconomics says
analysis_details: The headline 0.2% MM was a touch better than the consensus view looking for 0.0%; ex-autos was also above consensus, as was the control group. However, there was some chunky downward revisions to the December data, which was already disappointing. Pantheon say the revisions imply a 0.2ppt downward revision to Q4 GDP growth, but say that is not the end of the story: "The official data are subject to endless further revisions, and we remain of the view that eventually they will be revised higher, in keeping with past experience when the numbers undershoot the Redbook," Pantheon said. "To be clear, we are not arguing here that the true rate of growth of retail sales remains at last year's peak; that can’t happen, given the fading boost from the tax cuts and the drop in gas prices in Q4. But the December plunge probably overstates the downshift substantially." Pantheon also says the details of the January report suggest the rebound was uneven, but overall "these data signal a clear increase in total consumers' spending in January, but the adverse base effect from December's drop - which will be revised down - means that Q1 real consumption will struggle mightily to reach 2% growth, and a mere 1% is entirely possible," Pantheon notes.

PRIMER: Trump 2020 Budget to be announced on Monday
content:
US President Trump will release the 2020 budget on Monday (comes into effect in October), and set up a clash with Congress. The requests are a signalling exercise; it is Congress that sets the budget numbers, and Trump’s budget won’t get very far. But it will set up election themes, and also raise concerns of another government shutdown when current funding runs out at the end of September, if Trump threatens to veto any spending plan that falls short of his request. 

* TRUMP TO REQUEST USD 8.6BLN OF FUNDING FOR BORDER WALL: That would be more than six times what Congress allocated for border projects in each of the last two fiscal years, Reuters reported; the request will not likely get through the Democrat-controlled House. Nevertheless, the request and likely rejection sets up the issue of border security for the 2020 Presidential Campaign, where ‘Finish the Wall’ catchphrase may gain more prominence.

* DEFENCE SPENDING EXPECTED TO BE BOOSTED: Specifically, the funding will be requested through a boost to the Pentagon’s Overseas Contingency Operations (aka the War Fund). It’s a way to increase military spending without raising caps that were set in 2011. The move is essentially aimed at increasing defence spending without reaching a deal with Democrats to raise domestic spending, The Hill explains. As part of the request, Trump will reportedly seek funding for a new Space Force, branched within the Air Force.

* DOMESTIC SPENDING CUTS: The White House has proposed a 5% spending cut across Federal Agencies, with the exception of the Defence budget. Trump previously proposed spending cuts on domestic programs have largely been ignored by Congress. Democrats are likely to give Trump fierce resistance to proposed cuts in education, health and environmental protections, CNN reported. 

* FORECASTS: The economic projections will likely pencil in growth above 3%, and will likely propose taking longer to balance the books than Republicans have advocated in the past, Politico reported. (exp. 3.2% in 2019, 3.1% in 2020, 3% in 2021, 2.8% in 2026, and a 10-year forecast of 3.0%; the proposal will reportedly see a balanced budget in 2034, rather than the typical 10-year horizon that has been a goal for Republicans).

subject: ANALYSIS - BREXIT BREIFING: The state of play ahead of Tuesday's Meaningful vote
content:
* MAY FACING DEFEAT: UK PM May will on Tuesday likely lose her second Brexit Meaningful Vote by a margin greater than the 230 seen at January's first Meaningful Vote, according to the Sunday Times, and even "optimists" are said to see a majority of 150 against her deal. Cabinet members issued familiar warnings about how Brexit might not happen at all if they fail to back May’s deal.

* MAY UNDER PRESSURE TO QUIT: May could yet secure the support of Brexiteers in her own party if she pledged to step down by June so that a new Prime Minister can lead the next round of negotiations with the EU, the Sunday Times said. One aide was said to have predicted that if Labour tabled another motion of no confidence in the Government, Tories might vote for it to bring May down.

* THIS WEEK'S VOTES: To avoid humiliation, plans are reportedly being drawn-up to offer lawmakers the chance to vote on a motion that would outline the deal it would like, in order to show the EU what terms could be acceptable to Parliament. There is also a possibility that if the Meaningful Vote is rejected on Tuesday, planned votes on whether to rule out a no-deal Brexit and whether to extend Article 50 could be scrapped so May can attempt once more to try and secure concessions from the EU at the 21 March EU summit, The Times added.

* AWAITING ATTORNEY GENERAL’S OPINION: Passage of the Withdrawal Agreement (WA) likely will require Attorney General Geoffrey Cox to issue a legal opinion – expected late Sunday or early Monday – that the ‘Backstop’ is not legally binding indefinitely and the DUP and ERG to support his finding, Barclays explains. That seems very improbable, and accordingly, May’s deal is likely to suffer defeat.

* GBP SCENARIO 1: Meaningful Vote fails (Tue)/no-deal blocked (Wed/Thu)/vote to extend A50 passes (Wed/Thu) (likely). Barclays says initial GBP reaction would be negative. Focus will then shift to 21 March summit, where any signs of a longer extension could lead to a rally. 

* GBP SCENARIO 2: Meaningful Vote passes (somewhat likely). Barclays says it could open the door for new post-referendum highs.

* GBP SCENARIO 3: All votes fail (unlikely). Barclays sees GBP real effective exchange rate -2.5% as markets price higher probability of no-deal Brexit. Focus then shifts to 21 March summit where GBP will be almost entirely sensitive to Brexit newsflow. 

* GBP SCENARIO 4: meaningful vote fails/MPs vote for no-deal (highly unlikely): Barclays says GBP REER -5%.

* POSSIBLE ARTICLE 50 EXTENSION – 18/APR? 23/MAY? 23/Jun?: If MPs vote to extend the Article 50 process, in addition to the UK’s approval, every EU member would be required to agree. The message from the EU has been mixed; while some think it is a sensible idea, others say the process should only be extended if there is a good reason for it. Assuming that the EU agrees, the process could be pushed from the UK’s current Brexit leave date 29 March, to 18 April – the last day that the European Parliament can vote before breaking up ahead of May’s elections; the European Parliament has yet to even debate the Brexit deal, and has therefore not yet voted on it. It is likely, however, that if the UK votes for what is available, EU lawmakers will likely follow suit. The current exit date is enshrined into UK law, and that would need to be changed; BBC says a push to 23 May has emerged as a possible new Brexit day to allow the UK two months to fully prepare itself for leaving, and this would also mean the UK departs ahead of the 23-26 May European Parliament elections. IF no agreement between the UK and EU on the backstop is seen, a longer delay to exit become possible. A push to the end of June – 23rd is capturing imagines since it would coincide with the Brexit referendum anniversary – would be an admission that more time is needed, though new MEPs take their place in Parliament in early July, suggesting that nothing could be voted on until then at the very earliest, a scenario that not be ideal for either UK or EU. If the process cannot be wrapped up by July, then scenarios of 2021 come into focus (EU officials are said to have mulled a delay until then, BBC reported), though this may not be palatable for Brexiteers, and thus, may split the government and lead to another strategy before then.

* NORWAY STYLE: Meanwhile cross-party pro-EU lawmakers are said to be drawing up a new Brexit political declaration that commits the UK to a Norway style relationship with the EU, which could be tabled if May loses Tuesday's vote. And on the government side, Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly preparing a GBP 20bln 'bribe' in his budget, if May's deal is carried on Tuesday; the Chancellor had previously warned of a return to austerity if May's plans are rejected.

* NAMES IN THE FRAME TO REPLACE MAY: The four leading names to succeed May: current Foreign Minister Jeremy Hunt, current Home Secretary Sajid Javid, former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, and former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.

content:

  • Boeing (BA) – The aerospace/defence co. is under pressure again after another Boeing 737 Max 8 crashed on an Ethiopian Airlines flight
  • Nvidia (NVDA), Mellanox (MLNX) – The chipmaker is to buy Israeli based competitor Mellanox (MLNX) for USD 6.9bln in cash

11th March 2019

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech behemoth has been upgraded back to Buy at BAML, which raised its price target to USD 210 from USD 180, citing supply chain order cuts stabilising and a “large reversal of inventory overhang”. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – The aerospace/defence co. is under pressure again after another Boeing 737 Max 8 crashed on an Ethiopian Airlines flight just after take-off from Ethiopia to Kenya, the crash killed all 157 passengers and just a few months after the Lion Air crash last year. The co. has said that as of yet there is no need to issue new guidance, but it has delayed the debut launch of its 777x widebody aircraft. In the fall out, WSJ reports China has ordered all of its countries’ airlines to ground all 737 Max 8 aircraft. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • DowDuPont (DWDP) – The chemicals co. announced two additional board members, Dr. Klaus Engel and Rebecca Liebert, for Corteva Agriscience, its agriculture unit. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker’s shortage of CPU is reported to be exacerbated by a pick up in demand for Google’s (GOOGL) Chromebooks which use Intel processors. (DigiTimes)
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM) - The bank is merging its middle-market technology and emerging growth commercial banking units to augment its start-up operations. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The FBI are probing one of the retailer’s tech contractors, Compucom, over whether it withdrew sensitive information from email accounts at the co. (NY Times)

S&P500

  • Barrick Gold (GOLD), Newmont Mining (NEM) – As previously suggested, the two gold miners have entered a JV for a merger of their Nevada operations, where it sees USD 5bln worth of synergies, ownership will be 61.5% Barrick and 38.5% Newmont; consequentially, Barrick will remove its full acquisition offer for Newmont. (Newswires)
  • Danaher (DHR) – The medtech co. has raised its quarterly dividend to USD 0.17 from USD 0.16. (Newswires)
  • Elanco Animal Health (ELAN), Eli Lilly (LLY) – Elanco announced that it is now a fully independent company following Eli’s exchange offer. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The industrials co. has had its share price target lowered to USD 14 from USD 15 at Citi, citing absent improving cash on a reasonable timeframe. (Newswires)
  • Medtronic (MDT) – The medtech co. has authorised an additional USD 6bln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Occidental (OXY) – The oil co. has become one the largest US shale exporters, with the co. planning to double crude exports to 600,000 BPD in 2020. (Newswires)
  • Southwest (LUV) – The airline and its mechanics union have been warned by the FAA that their dispute could harm the airline’s safety, NY Times reports. Elsewhere, following the recent Ethiopian Airlines Boeing (BA) 737 MAX 8 crash the co. said it is continuing to fly the aircraft, which consists of almost 90% of its fleet. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes bullishly on Delta Air Lines (DAL), citing its low P/E, Intel (INTC) due to its low relative valuation, and on offshore drilling stocks Transocean (RIG), Diamond Offshore Drilling (DO), Ensco (ESV) and Rowan (RDC), citing capital being over-concentrated in the land-based shale boom. The publication is sceptical on Dollar Tree’s (DLTR) recent surge. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Celgene (CELG) – the pharma co. has submitted a Marketing Authorization Application to European regulators for its multiple sclerosis treatment, ozanimod. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co. is suing two Ukrainian quiz developers over a browser extension that took personal information and put in additional ads for over 60,000 users, The Verge reports. Elsewhere, CNBC reports that the co. is under pressure from menopausal product companies that have had their ads removed, citing that Facebook does not remove erectile dysfunction adverts for men. (CNBC/Newswires)
  • Nvidia (NVDA), Mellanox (MLNX) – The chipmaker is to buy Israeli based competitor Mellanox (MLNX) for USD 6.9bln in cash coming from its balance sheet, this comes after Intel (INTC) previously bid USD 6bln. Nvidia’s CFO said on a conservative basis the co. sees no initial revenue synergies. (Newswires)
  • Take-Two (TTWO) – The videogame developer’s CEO Strauss Zelnick said on CNBC’s Fast Money that competitor Fortnite is a “great thing for the industry” as it brings in new gamers and believes that Take-Two’s NBA 2K franchise is “the one to watch” in the esports space. (CNBC)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker has decided not to close half of the stores it previously planned to shut but says that there will be 3% price rises on its vehicles, except for its USD 35,000 version of its Model 3. The co. has filed to sell shares as part of its dividend reinvestment plan. Elsewhere, Business Insider reports that employees have said morale at the co. has fallen sharply in the wake of store closures and layoffs. (Newswires/BI)

subject: Nomura quants say systematic stock selling pressure caused by the liquidation of long positions will likely calm down after the middle of next week
content:
• The bank notes US stock market remained sluggish, with S&P500 losing its upward momentum steadily. “It currently stands at ~2,750, which is our estimate of the average entry cost or breakeven level for CTAs’ existing long positions,” Nomura says. “In order to avoid making further losses, CTAs need to reduce their risk exposure.”
  • Nomura says that an insufficient stock market rebound is more likely to induce more selling by CTAs at relatively advantageous price levels. “Indeed, CTAs have so far already unwound 50-60% of their ‘loss-making’ long positions, according to Nomura’s real-time estimate.”
  • This time, CTAs’ selling pressure has begun to soften earlier than in previous risk-off moves, Nomura says, “as they have not excessively accumulated long positions by raising their leverage ratio.” Nomura adds that “in light of past CTA positioning patterns, systematic stock selling pressure caused by the liquidation of long positions will likely calm down after the middle of next week.”

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European equity indices are essentially unchanged, while Dow futures underperform due to heavyweight Boeing
  • Brexit deadlock continues, recent reports suggest that PM May may change tomorrows vote from meaningful to provisional
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US retail sales (Jan), BoE’s Haskel, US supply. Note: US clocks have changed (London-NY gap is now 4 hours)

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded somewhat indecisive as the region digested Friday’s mixed US jobs data in which NFPs severely missed expectations and although the declines across the major US indices were only mild, the S&P 500 still posted a 5th consecutive daily loss and its worst weekly performance YTD. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were mixed with Energy the underperformer in Australia which some attributed to news of Norway’s sovereign wealth fund exiting energy companies and with the Japanese benchmark reflecting a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) eventually outperformed despite a steep drop in lending data over the weekend, as some attributed the sharp decline in New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing to seasonal factors, while the PBoC also reportedly pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and reducing the cost of borrowing. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with price action contained by the indecisive risk tone and lack of BoJ presence in the market.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7202 (Prev. 6.7235)

US NEC Director Kudlow said US and China are still negotiating over the phone and that a Trump- Xi meeting may happen late this month or next. (Newswires)

China Mofcom stated that US-China trade talks have made substantial progress and leaders have agreed to work towards removal of tariffs. (Newswires)

PBoC pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and lowering borrowing costs after data showed a sharp decline in lending data due to seasonal factors. Furthermore, PBoC Governor Yi Gang stated there is still some room for a RRR cut although the amount of room is less compared with a few years ago and there were also comments from PBoC Deputy Governor Pan that they will keep liquidity ample and set up counter cyclical adjustments, while a central bank official also noted that February money supply data is normal and inline with historical trends. (Newswires/Yahoo)

Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Feb) 885.8B vs. Exp. 975.0B (Prev. 3230.0B). (Newswires) Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Feb) 703.0B vs. Exp. 1300.0B (Prev. 4640.0B). Chinese Money Supply M2 (Feb) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 8.4% (Prev. 8.4%) Chinese CPI (Feb) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.7%). (Newswires) Chinese PPI (Feb) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)

US

US President Trump will release the 2020 budget today (comes into effect in October) in which he is to request USD 8.6bln of funding for border wall and is to ask Congress to reduce non-defense spending by an average of 5% in fiscal 2020 budget. Furthermore, growth is exp. 3.2% in 2019, 3.1% in 2020, 3.0% in 2021 and a 10-year forecast of 3.0%, while the proposal will see a balanced budget in 2034 rather than the typical 10-year horizon that has been a goal for Republicans. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) commented that downside risks to the economic outlook have increased and that more economies began to slow 6 months ago, while he added that US economic outlook is still favourable but that trade talks have added to the uncertainty. Fed Chair Powell also stated the economy is in a good place and rates are appropriate considering muted inflation, while he added the Fed does not feel any hurry to change interest rates again and will wait to observe how global conditions evolve before making any changes. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) commented that downside risks to the economic outlook have increased and that more economies began to slow 6 months ago, while he added that US economic outlook is still favourable but that trade talks have added to the uncertainty.. (BBC)

UK PM May has reportedly been warned by MPs that the Brexit vote must be put on hold if she fails to secure significant concessions from Brussels. (Times)

EU is preparing to impose punitive conditions on UK for agreeing a Brexit extension with EU member states said to be toughening their stance by demanding legal and financial conditions such as a higher divorce bill in return for an extension. (Telegraph)

Only two cabinet members reportedly still support PM May, according to a cabinet minister. (Telegraph)

Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said the Labour party will not push for a vote on a second referendum even if PM May’s deal is defeated. (The Times)

Senior Brexiteers wanted PM May’s team that she will only get her deal passed if she offers to resign by June. (The Times)

UK Chancellor Hammond will reportedly offer Tory MPs a fund pump of GBP 20bln this week to “end austerity” if they support PM May’s deal. (The Times)

There are talks of PM May having a "conditional" vote on her dream Brexit deal, rather than one on the table, as a way of showing what could get through HoC; according to FT's Political Editor. (FT)

UK Government sources says UK PM May has no plans to head to Brussels following the deadlock in talks with the EU. (Newswires)

EU Sources are rubbishing claims of extra payments being attached to a Brexit deal, adding that the EU expects the UK to pay what has been signed up to; Guardian's Rankin. (Twitter)

The chances of tomorrows meaningful vote being pulled are 50/50 says Tory Brexiteer Mark Francois; Sun's Dathan. (Twitter)

ITV's Peston notes that he can find no one in the Cabinet or on the backbenches who any longer believes Theresa May will be PM for longer than a few weeks. (Twitter)

PM May is meeting with senior aides in No10 to plot a way through the week, told that it is most likely PM will change the vote tomorrow from a meaningful vote to a provisional one; Sun's Dunn. (Twitter)

- Adding that if PM May can produce a commons majority for a detailed deal on the backstop then the EU may buckle and concede at the Council meeting on March 21/22.

- Dunn adds that he was told this was discussed by the PM with EU Commission President Juncker last night, and No10 considers it a win that Juncker agreed to continue technical negotiations  between officials by the end of the call.

 

Irish PM Varadkar says an Article 50 extension would have to be with a purpose, adding that no one wants a rolling Brexit cliff edge. (Newswires)

 

BoE reportedly tightened liquidity buffers ahead of Brexit in which it asked some UK banks to triple their holdings of easy-to-sell assets to cope in the event of a market crash from a potential no-deal Brexit. (FT)

ECB's Coeure (Neutral) said he does not see a need to restart asset purchases and added that the ECB does not see a recession at the moment. (Newswires)

German Industrial Output MM* Jan -0.8% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -0.4%). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

After opening with gains of around 0.5%, major European indices are largely unchanged [Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%] following an indecisive lead from Asia where Chinese stocks eventually outperformed. Goldman Sachs noted that China A shares could be set for large gains as “fear of missing out” takes hold. If retail optimism were to return to its peaks in 2015 and 2018, the CSI 300 would give approximately 50% and 15% potential upside respectively from current levels, Goldman says. Equities across Europe have somewhat waned off opening highs with the FTSE 100 (+0.8%) holding its composure amid a weak domestic currency ahead of a series of Parliamentary votes this week. Meanwhile, Spain’s IBEX (-0.1%) underperforms as heavyweight BBVA (Unch) swings between gains and losses amid reports the Co. is planning board changes in the coming months. Over in Germany, Wirecard (+5.6%) shares lift the benchmark as the Co. expects the final report on fraud allegations soon (Note: Shorting ban on Co shares are still ongoing). Deutsche Bank (+2.2%) also supports the German index amid pre-market reports that the Co. and Commerzbank (+4.6%) have begun tentative merger talks. Finally, Dow Jones Mar’19 futures dipped lower as Boeing shares dropped 10% in pre-market trade following the weekend Boeing 737 Max 8 crash on its way to Nairobi, marking the second disaster for the jet in five months. Several airlines have since grounded the Boeing jet, whilst Airbus shares (+0.4%) are little moved.

FX

GBP – Sterling remains under pressure across the board, irrespective of latest bullish bank calls (this time via Eur/Gbp rather than Cable), as talks between UK and EU officials on changes to the back-stop continue to hit a brick wall, and the prospects of a breakthrough looks increasingly bleak before Tuesday’s meaningful vote. Indeed, given the ongoing impasse and indications that PM May’s deal will be roundly rejected again, rumours are now circulating about a provisional or conditional vote before going back to Parliament, and with the possibility of adding the Cox amendment to try and coerce more support. Cable briefly reclaimed 1.3000+ status amidst reports that the EU will not demand more money from Britain in exchange for an extension to the March 29 Article 50 deadline, in contrast to earlier suggestions, but is back below the round number and not far from circa 1.2950 lows hit when stops were said to have been tripped around the 1.2960 level (trend-line support). Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp is hugging the top of a 0.8675-40 range, leaving the aforementioned short strategy underwater at this stage, as the institution entered at 0.8630 with a 0.8760 stop and 0.8400 target.

NOK – The Norwegian Crown is also bucking an otherwise relatively muted and rangebound start to the week for G10 currencies/pairings, but outperforming in wake of significantly stronger than forecast CPI data, and especially the core inflation measure. Eur/Nok fell from 9.8250+ to just shy of 9.7600 in response, but is currently holding near 9.7700.

EUR/NZD/AUD/CAD/JPY/CHF –  All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the single currency reclaiming some lost ground after its sharp post-ECB demise, but struggling to sustain recovery gains much beyond 1.1250 with resistance seen at 1.1270 (Fib level) and 1.1298, while hefty options may also keep Eur/Usd in check given 2.7 bn sitting between 1.1300-20 and not much on the downside until 1.7 bn at the 1.1200 strike. Meanwhile, the Kiwi is still performing better than the Aussie down under, partly due to post-NFP weakness in its US counterpart and switching via the Aud/Nzd cross that is pivoting 1.0350. Consequently, Nzd/Usd is hovering just above 0.6800, while Aud/Usd is capped circa 0.7050. Elsewhere, the Loonie continues to benefit from upbeat Canadian jobs data in contrast to the headline US tally, and firmer crude prices to an extent, as Usd/Cad eases back from recent 1.3460 highs. Turning to Usd/Jpy and Usd/Chf, both are nearer the apex of respective 111.30-110.90 and 1.0095-70 trading parameters, as the broad Dollar and DXY regain some composure – index meandering between 97.500-250.

FIXED INCOME

The ongoing malaise and heightened uncertainty on the eve of what could well be 3 consecutive and pivotal Parliamentary votes on the fate of Brexit has underpinned UK debt, albeit belatedly, as Gilts grind higher to reach a new 127.39 Liffe peak for the day (+26 ticks). Meanwhile, Bunds have also regained composure after a deeper retreat from best levels to 164.32 at one stage (-7 ticks), and another sell-off in Italian bonds could well be supporting the 10 year Eurozone benchmark. However, US Treasuries are not that impressed as futures remain depressed and the curve steeper in wake of latest comments from Fed chair Powell reiterating an upbeat assessment of the economy, but no rush to hike rates again. Note also, key retail sales data on tap later, and Usd38 bn 3 year supply.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are trading with firm gains of around USD 0.50/bbl each with recent upside exacerbated by comments from a Saudi Official which stated that the Kingdom plans to cut April crude exports below 7mln BPD. This follows comments from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih last week who noted that the Kingdom is currently exporting around 7-8mln BPD of crude. Furthermore, the Official stated that Saudi are to keep oil production in April well below 10mln BPD, compared with February’s output of 10.316mln BPD; according to Industry sources. In the metals complex, spot gold remains sub-1300/oz as the yellow metal is largely dictated by USD-action. RBC notes that gold may still be “well off its YTD highs” although they caveat this by stating “[they] remain of the view that macro headwinds have softened”. The bank also reiterated their 2019 annual average price forecast at USD 1338/oz, and launched a 2020 forecast at USD 1367/oz. Elsewhere, Dalian iron ore prices fell as much as 3.6%, hitting the lowest levels for this month so far as demand waned due to restrictions on steel productions.

US President Trump administration officials are reportedly divided over NOPEC legislation that would allow the government to sue OPEC nations for attempting to control oil prices. (Axios)

Sinopec and PetroChina are to shut down several refineries with tens of millions of tonnes of total capacity for several months due to overhaul work. (Newswires)

Libya is currently producing 1.17mln BPD, including 200K BPD from restarted Sharara Oil Field (300K BPD) where full production is expected this week. (Newswires)

Saudi Official says that they plan to cut April crude exports below 7mln BPD despite strong demand. (Newswires)

- Are to keep oil production in April well below 10mln BPD

- Add that they are committed to oil market rebalancing, and they expect other producers to show similar commitment

- Saudi Aramco’s Crude oil allocation in April are 635k BPD lower than their customer requested volumes

 

Global oil demand to grow by an average 1.2mln BPD a year through to 2024; IEA.

- Report adds that the US are to become a net oil exporter in 2021 and global oil output capacity to increase by 5.9mln BPD by 2024.

 

Libya's Harouge crude oil pipeline is leaking following a car crash; NOC. (Newswires)

subject: UK Junior Brexit Minister says, as far as he is aware, the Meaningful Vote will go ahead this week; adds that if the deal is rejected, there is an opportunity to remove no-deal scenario
Saudi Aramco board to meet this week to approave SABIC M&A bond plan, could issue USD 10bln, sources say
Nvidia (NVDA) to acquire Mellanox (MLNX) for USD 6.9bln (USD 125/shr in cash)
Senior Tory MP suggests that UK PM May would lose a no-confidence vote this week if the meaningful vote is pulled tomorrow, as according to Newton-Dunn of the Sun

Eur/Nok fell from 9.8250+ to just shy of 9.7600 in response, but is currently holding near 9.7700.

EUR/NZD/AUD/CAD/JPY/CHF - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the single currency reclaiming some lost ground after its sharp post-ECB demise, but struggling to sustain recovery gains much beyond 1.1250 with resistance seen at 1.1270 (Fib level) and 1.1298, while hefty options may also keep Eur/Usd in check given 2.7 bn sitting between 1.1300-20 and not much on the downside until 1.7 bn at the 1.1200 strike. Meanwhile, the Kiwi is still performing better than the Aussie down under, partly due to post-NFP weakness in its US counterpart and switching via the Aud/Nzd cross that is pivoting 1.0350. Consequently, Nzd/Usd is hovering just above 0.6800, while Aud/Usd is capped circa 0.7050. Elsewhere, the Loonie continues to benefit from upbeat Canadian jobs data in contrast to the headline US tally, and firmer crude prices to an extent, as Usd/Cad eases back from recent 1.3460 highs. Turning to Usd/Jpy and Usd/Chf, both are nearer the apex of respective 111.30-110.90 and 1.0095-70 trading parameters, as the broad Dollar and DXY regain some composure – index meandering between 97.500-250.

FIXED INCOME

The ongoing malaise and heightened uncertainty on the eve of what could well be 3 consecutive and pivotal Parliamentary votes on the fate of Brexit has underpinned UK debt, albeit belatedly, as Gilts grind higher to reach a new 127.39 Liffe peak for the day (+26 ticks). Meanwhile, Bunds have also regained composure after a deeper retreat from best levels to 164.32 at one stage (-7 ticks), and another sell-off in Italian bonds could well be supporting the 10 year Eurozone benchmark. However, US Treasuries are not that impressed as futures remain depressed and the curve steeper in wake of latest comments from Fed chair Powell reiterating an upbeat assessment of the economy, but no rush to hike rates again. Note also, key retail sales data on tap later, and Usd38 bn 3 year supply.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are trading with firm gains of around USD 0.50/bbl each with recent upside exacerbated by comments from a Saudi Official which stated that the Kingdom plans to cut April crude exports below 7mln BPD. This follows comments from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih last week who noted that the Kingdom is currently exporting around 7-8mln BPD of crude. Furthermore, the Official stated that Saudi are to keep oil production in April well below 10mln BPD, compared with February’s output of 10.316mln BPD; according to Industry sources. In the metals complex, spot gold remains sub-1300/oz as the yellow metal is largely dictated by USD-action. RBC notes that gold may still be “well off its YTD highs” although they caveat this by stating “[they] remain of the view that macro headwinds have softened”. The bank also reiterated their 2019 annual average price forecast at USD 1338/oz, and launched a 2020 forecast at USD 1367/oz. Elsewhere, Dalian iron ore prices fell as much as 3.6%, hitting the lowest levels for this month so far as demand waned due to restrictions on steel productions.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Pound undermined by Brexit deadlock, Norwegian Crown underpinned by CPI
content:
GBP 

Sterling remains under pressure across the board, irrespective of latest bullish bank calls (this time via Eur/Gbp rather than Cable), as talks between UK and EU officials on changes to the back-stop continue to hit a brick wall, and the prospects of a breakthrough looks increasingly bleak before Tuesday’s meaningful vote. Indeed, given the ongoing impasse and indications that PM May’s deal will be roundly rejected again, rumours are now circulating about a provisional or conditional vote before going back to Parliament, and with the possibility of adding the Cox amendment to try and coerce more support. Cable briefly reclaimed 1.3000+ status amidst reports that the EU will not demand more money from Britain in exchange for an extension to the March 29 Article 50 deadline, in contrast to earlier suggestions, but is back below the round number and not far from circa 1.2950 lows hit when stops were said to have been tripped around the 1.2960 level (trend-line support). Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp is hugging the top of a 0.8675-40 range, leaving the aforementioned short strategy underwater at this stage, as the institution entered at 0.8630 with a 0.8760 stop and 0.8400 target.

subject: BoJ Board Member Kataoka says he think the possibility of the inflation rate rising toward 2 percent is low at the moment and that the momentum of inflation has not been strengthened.
content:
• He considers it appropriate to strengthen monetary easing in order to encourage further widening of the output gap within positive territory.

  • He consider that the pace of pick-up in Japan's economy will likely be slow from the scheduled consumption tax hike in October onward, mainly because the heightening of uncertainties in the global economy

11th March 2019

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded somewhat indecisive as the region digested Friday’s mixed US jobs data in which NFPs severely missed expectations and although the declines across the major US indices were only mild, the S&P 500 still posted a 5th consecutive daily loss and its worst weekly performance YTD. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were mixed with Energy the underperformer in Australia which some attributed to news of Norway’s sovereign wealth fund exiting energy companies and with the Japanese benchmark reflecting a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) eventually outperformed despite a steep drop in lending data over the weekend, as some attributed the sharp decline in New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing to seasonal factors, while the PBoC also reportedly pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and reducing the cost of borrowing.

FTSE

OTHER UK COMPANIES

One Savings Bank (OSB LN)/ Charter Court Financial (CCFS LN) – The Co’s have reportedly been in on-off discussions for months regarding a all share merger to create a lender worth over GBP 1.6bln. With the talks now said to be at an advanced stage. (Sky)

content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded somewhat indecisive as the region digested Friday’s mixed US jobs data, China outperformed on PBoC pledge to further support the slowing economy
  • China reportedly removed the trip to Mar-a-Lago from Chinese President Xi's calendar, US and China are still negotiating over the phone
  • Brexit talks between the UK and the EU remain at an impasse, Downing Street has said, talks are to resume today
  • UK PM May has reportedly been warned by MPs that the Brexit vote must be put on hold, meanwhile EU is preparing to impose punitive conditions on UK for agreeing a Brexit extension
  • In FX markets, the DXY stabilized from Friday’s data-induced brief pullback, GBP/USD was the underperformer on several bearish Brexit-related stories
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German trade balance, Norwegian inflation, US retail sales (Jan), BoE’s Haskel, US supply. Note: US clocks have changed (London-NY gap is now 4 hours)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded somewhat indecisive as the region digested Friday’s mixed US jobs data in which NFPs severely missed expectations and although the declines across the major US indices were only mild, the S&P 500 still posted a 5th consecutive daily loss and its worst weekly performance YTD. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were mixed with Energy the underperformer in Australia which some attributed to news of Norway’s sovereign wealth fund exiting energy companies and with the Japanese benchmark reflecting a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) eventually outperformed despite a steep drop in lending data over the weekend, as some attributed the sharp decline in New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing to seasonal factors, while the PBoC also reportedly pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and reducing the cost of borrowing. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with price action contained by the indecisive risk tone and lack of BoJ presence in the market.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7202 (Prev. 6.7235)

China reportedly removed the trip to Mar-a-Lago from Chinese President Xi's calendar, while US NEC Director Kudlow said US and China are still negotiating over the phone and that a Trump- Xi meeting may happen late this month or next. (Newswires)

China Mofcom stated that US-China trade talks have made substantial progress and leaders have agreed to work towards removal of tariffs. (Newswires)

PBoC pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and lowering borrowing costs after data showed a sharp decline in lending data due to seasonal factors. Furthermore, PBoC Governor Yi Gang stated there is still some room for a RRR cut although the amount of room is less compared with a few years ago and there were also comments from PBoC Deputy Governor Pan that they will keep liquidity ample and set up counter cyclical adjustments, while a central bank official also noted that February money supply data is normal and inline with historical trends. (Newswires/Yahoo)

Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Feb) 885.8B vs. Exp. 975.0B (Prev. 3230.0B). (Newswires) Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Feb) 703.0B vs. Exp. 1300.0B (Prev. 4640.0B). Chinese Money Supply M2 (Feb) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 8.4% (Prev. 8.4%) Chinese CPI (Feb) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.7%). (Newswires) Chinese PPI (Feb) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)

 

UK/EU

Brexit talks between the UK and the EU remain at an impasse, Downing Street has said. Talks between the two sides are to resume this morning with the aim of securing changes ahead of tomorrow’s meaningful vote. (BBC)

UK PM May has reportedly been warned by MPs that the Brexit vote must be put on hold if she fails to secure significant concessions from Brussels. (Times)

EU is preparing to impose punitive conditions on UK for agreeing a Brexit extension with EU member states said to be toughening their stance by demanding legal and financial conditions such as a higher divorce bill in return for an extension. (Telegraph)

Only two cabinet members reportedly still support PM May, according to a cabinet minister. (Telegraph)

Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said the Labour party will not push for a vote on a second referendum even if PM May’s deal is defeated. (The Times)

Senior Brexiteers wanted PM May’s team that she will only get her deal passed if she offers to resign by June. (The Times)

UK Chancellor Hammond will reportedly offer Tory MPs a fund pump of GBP 20bln this week to “end austerity” if they support PM May’s deal. (The Times)

BoE reportedly tightened liquidity buffers ahead of Brexit in which it asked some UK banks to triple their holdings of easy-to-sell assets to cope in the event of a market crash from a potential no-deal Brexit. (FT)

UK Brexit Minister Barclay said on Friday that it currently isn't the time to rerun old arguments with a very real deadline looming and that the UK has put forward clear new proposals and now need to agree a balanced solution that works on both sides. (Newswires)

UK rejected the EU Brexit offer on Friday and a UK government source suggested they were not impressed by Barnier's tweets.  Furthermore, DUP’s Dodds said the EU offer was neither realistic nor sensible and that it disrespects the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK, while Dodd’s also suggested it was an attempt to get ahead in a possible blame game but added there is still time to get a deal. (Newswires)

ECB's Coeure (Neutral) said he does not see a need to restart asset purchases and added that the ECB does not see a recession at the moment. (Newswires) 

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY stabilized from Friday’s data-induced brief pullback in which selling pressure from the worst NFP reading since September 2017, was suppressed by a decline in the Unemployment Rate and better than expected Average Earnings. The composure of the greenback and indecisive risk tone kept price action across most major currencies range-bound in which USD/JPY oscillated around the 111.00 level and with antipodeans tentative after a slowdown in lending and mixed inflation data from China, while EUR/USD was little changed at the 1.1200 handle amid light weekend news flow from the continent although Barclays had recommended shorting EUR/GBP with a target at 0.8400 and stop at 0.8760. Conversely, GBP/USD was the underperformer on several bearish Brexit-related stories including reports which suggested that only 2 cabinet members still support PM May and that she was warned by MPs to put the Brexit vote on hold, while the EU is also said to be preparing to impose punitive conditions on the UK including a higher divorce bill if the latter requests a Brexit extension. This saw the pair gap below several key technical levels including the psychological 1.3000 level, its 200 DMA and 61.8% Fibonacci retracement of the mid-to-late February rally. 

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mildly positive but with gains restricted amid an indecisive risk tone, with WTI crude futures marginally positive following a decline in the latest Baker Hughes rig count and reports China’s top oil firms are shutting down several refineries for overhauls. Elsewhere, a stable greenback kept gold prices in check and below the USD 1300/oz level, while copper also eked small gains as China bourses eventually outperformed their regional peers.

Baker Hughes (March 8) oil rigs -9 at 834, nat gas rigs -2 at 193, total rigs -11 at 1027. (Newswires)

US President Trump administration officials are reportedly divided over NOPEC legislation that would allow the government to sue OPEC nations for attempting to control oil prices. (Axios)

Sinopec and PetroChina are to shut down several refineries with tens of millions of tonnes of total capacity for several months due to overhaul work. (Newswires) 

 

US

As the Tsy complex wrapped up for the week, the T Note future added only 3+ ticks at settlement, despite the NFP headline mis which took the June contract to highs of 122-31, and then snap to lows around 122-19, before continuing its sideways grind at relatively unchanged levels. There was buying after the Europeans had left for the week, which took the contract form around 122-21 to around 122-26. At settlement, major curve spreads were slightly narrower, but under 1bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled 3+ ticks higher at 122-24+.

US President Trump will release the 2020 budget today (comes into effect in October) in which he is to request USD 8.6bln of funding for border wall and is to ask Congress to reduce non-defense spending by an average of 5% in fiscal 2020 budget. Furthermore, growth is exp. 3.2% in 2019, 3.1% in 2020, 3.0% in 2021 and a 10-year forecast of 3.0%, while the proposal will see a balanced budget in 2034 rather than the typical 10-year horizon that has been a goal for Republicans. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) commented that downside risks to the economic outlook have increased and that more economies began to slow 6 months ago, while he added that US economic outlook is still favourable but that trade talks have added to the uncertainty. Fed Chair Powell also stated the economy is in a good place and rates are appropriate considering muted inflation, while he added the Fed does not feel any hurry to change interest rates again and will wait to observe how global conditions evolve before making any changes. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks eventually traded mostly positive on what was an indecisive session in the aftermath of mixed US jobs data and weak Chinese lending figures
content: Asia equity markets traded somewhat indecisive as the region digested Friday’s mixed US jobs data in which NFPs severely missed expectations and although the declines across the major US indices were only mild, the S&P 500 still posted a 5th consecutive daily loss and its worst weekly performance YTD. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were mixed with Energy the underperformer in Australia which some attributed to news of Norway’s sovereign wealth fund exiting energy companies and with the Japanese benchmark reflecting a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) eventually outperformed despite a steep drop in lending data over the weekend, as some attributed the sharp decline in New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing to seasonal factors, while the PBoC also reportedly pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and reducing the cost of borrowing. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with price action contained by the indecisive risk tone and lack of BoJ presence in the market.

ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) are mixed with Energy underperforming the broad lacklustre tone across Australia and with the Japanese benchmark meandering amid a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) outperform despite a steep drop in lending data over the weekend, as some attributed the sharp decline in New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing to seasonal factors, while the PBoC also reportedly pledged to further support the slowing economy by spurring loans and reducing the cost of borrowing.

In FX markets, the DXY has stabilized following the mild pullback in the aftermath of Friday’s mixed US jobs data, in which selling pressure from the worst NFP reading since September 2017 was suppressed by a decline in the Unemployment Rate and better than expected Average Earnings. The composure of the greenback and indecisive risk tone has kept price action across most major currencies range-bound with USD/JPY oscillating around the 111.00 level and with antipodeans also tentative after a slowdown in lending and mixed inflation data from China, while EUR/USD is little changed at the 1.1200 handle amid light weekend news flow from the continent although Barclays does recommend shorting EUR/GBP with a target at 0.8400 and stop at 0.8760. Conversely, GBP/USD is the underperformer on several bearish related stories including reports which suggested that only 2 cabinet members still support PM May and that she was warned by MPs to put the Brexit vote on hold, while the EU is also said to be preparing to impose punitive conditions on the UK including a higher divorce bill if the latter requests a Brexit extension. This saw the pair gap below several key technical levels including the psychological 1.3000 level, its 200 DMA and 61.8% Fibonacci retracement of the mid-to-late February rally.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued with price action contained by the indecisive risk tone and lack of BoJ presence in the market.
